question: Question_06_(f)
statement:
Suppose you expanded the same function \emph{$f$(x) = x} as in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)} except on the interval $0 \leq x \leq 2$. What would be the
\emph{form} (i.e., do not compute the coefficients) of the Fourier
series valid for this interval? What points on the plane would you plot
to produce a frequency-amplitude plot from this new Fourier series?
(Give the answer in terms of the coefficients in the new expansion.)
sols:
If we extend the domain from (0,1) to (0,2), the frequency will chenge.
Our original frequency was $\omega_n=\frac{n}{T}$ where T was 1. Now T
is 2 since interval has increased. Thus, new $\omega_n=\frac{n}{2}$.
However, the amplitude will not change.

$c_{n} = \int_{0}^{1} e^{-2\pi inx}f(x)dx= \frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{2} e^{-2\pi \frac{inx}{2}}f(x)dx$

As a result, new $c_n$ will be halved, but bigger range of integration
will put the value back increased by 2 again. Thus, amplitude is equal.
Although, $c_0$ is different.

$c_{0} = \frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{2} f(x)dx=\frac{1}{2}\left [\frac{1}{2}x^2 \right ]^2_0=1$

Thus new frequency-amplitude plot will be (0,1) and
$\left(\frac{n}{2},|c_n|\right)$
